p: The FTIR spectra of RO, ERO, and ARO are shown in Figure 2a. In the FTIR spectrum of RO, the characteristic peaks at 3010 cm −1 and 1760 cm −1 were attributed to the C=C–H and C=O stretching vibrations, respectively. In the spectrum of ERO, the new peaks at 910 cm −1 ( Figure 2a ERO at high resolution) and 3460 cm −1 were assigned to the stretching vibration of epoxy groups and hydroxyl group [ 26], respectively. At the same time, the peak at 3010 cm −1 was weakened, demonstrating that C=C–H bonds were partially oxidized to form epoxy groups. In the spectrum of ARO, the characteristic peak at 910 cm −1 disappeared and the peak at 3460 cm −1 was obviously enhanced, indicating that a small amount of hydroxyl groups transformed from epoxy group by a ring-opening reaction, which means that the RO was successfully modified.
